facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 230 of 1964 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 230 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 11, 1961 of the Madras High Court in S. C. Petition No. 165 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 11, 1961 of the Madras High Court in S. C. Petition No. 165 of 1960. Ganapathy Iyer and R. Thiagarajan, for the appellant.

facts.text: Madras High Court refused certificate under Art. 133(1)(a) and (b) on January 11, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is against the order,, of the High Court of Madras dated January 11, 1961 refusing the certificate under Art. 133 1  a  and  b  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Authorities under Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, Madras Act 11 of 1927 held premises No. 29 South Masi Street, Madurai constituted a temple.

anchor.surface_text: The authorities appointed under the Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, Madras Act 11 of 1927 having held that the premises No. 29 South Masi Street, Madurai, wherein the idol of Sri Srinivasaparumal and certain other idols were located constituted a temple within the meaning of the said Act,

facts.text: Appellant filed application in District Court for declaration that premises No. 29 South Masi Street, Madurai were private property and to set aside authorities' decision.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant filed an application in the District Court for a declaration that the said premises were private property and for an order setting aside the said decision.

facts.text: High Court order converted the application into a suit.

anchor.surface_text: The said application was by an order of the High Court companyverted into a suit.

facts.text: District Judge, Madurai decreed the suit in favour of appellant holding premises did not constitute a temple.

anchor.surface_text: The District Judge, Madurai, decreed the suit in favour of the appellant holding that the aforesaid premises did number companystitute a temple and set aside the decision of the said authorities.

facts.text: High Court reversed District Judge's judgment and held premises constituted a temple under Madras Act 19 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the High Court reversed the said judgment and decree and found that the premises in question companystituted a temple.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition for leave to appeal to Supreme Court claiming subject-matter value more than Rs. 20,000/- in District Court and High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon filed a petition for leave to appeal to this Court and submitted that the value of the subject- matter of dispute in the District Court as also in appeal in the High Court was more than Rs. 20,000/-

facts.text: High Court dismissed leave petition on grounds that subject-matter had no market value, clause b not applicable, no substantial question of law.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed that application on the following grounds  a  that the subject- matter of the dispute, whether it was a private or a public temple companyld have numbermarket value and therefore was incapable of valuation  b  that cl.  b  of Art. 133 1  companyld number apply as the judgment and decree passed by it did number involve directly or indirectly a claim or question res- pecting property of the value of Rs. 20,000/- or more and  c  that the appeal did number involve any substantial question of law.

facts.text: Appellant claimed property belonged to Thoguluva family and he managed it for the family.

anchor.surface_text: It may be observed that the appellant claimed that the property belonged to the Thoguluva family and he was in management thereof for and on behalf of the family.

facts.text: Suit initially filed as O.P. No. 37 of 1950 under s. 84(2) of Madras Act 11 of 1927.

anchor.surface_text: The suit in the first instance was filed by him in the form of an application, being O.P. No. 37 of 1950 under s. 84 2  of Madras Act 11 of 1927.

facts.text: Site of Mandapam originally property of Kuppaiyan and his undivided sons, not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: It does number appear to be in dispute that the site of the Mandapam and the structure standing thereon was originally the property of one Kuppaiyan and his undivided sons.

facts.text: In execution of decree in Suit No. 650 of 1882 against Kuppaiyan, property sold by public auction and purchased by Thoguluva Thirumalayyan for Rs. 1,060/-, per appellant's case.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case was that in execution of the decree in Suit No. 650 of 1882 passed against the said Kuppaiyan the property was sold by public auction and purchased by Thoguluva Thirumalayyan, the appellants ancestor, for a sum of Rs. 1,060/-.

facts.text: Descendants of Thoguluva Thirumalayyan improved original mandapam and added shops and constructions.

anchor.surface_text: The original mandapam was thereafter improved upon and some additional structures e.g., shops and other companystructions were added, the expenses for such repairs and additions having been met by the descendants of the said Thoguluva Thirumalayyan,

facts.text: Respondents claimed property was public temple for public worship and plaintiff's allegation of private property false.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the case of the respondents in their written statement was that the property was a public temple for public religious worship and that the allegation of the plaintiff that it was a private property capable of alienation was false and misleading.

facts.text: Shops constructed were let out to tenants for a number of years and property taxes levied by Madurai Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: There was evidence that the shops subsequently companystructed as aforesaid were let out to tenants for a number of years and property taxes were levied thereon by the Madhurai Municipality, presumably on their rateable value.

facts.text: Appellant stated property tax for half year ending September 30, 1950 was Rs. 94-0-6.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant, property tax for the half year ending September 30, 1950 was Rs. 94-0-6 and for the half year ending March 31, 1961 it was Rs. 130.36nP.

facts.text: Appellant stated property tax for half year ending March 31, 1961 was Rs. 130.36nP.

anchor.surface_text: According to him the half yearly tax would be equivalent to one months rent and on that basis the annual rental value would companye to Rs. 1,126-6-0 in 1950 and to Rs. 1,672.32nP in 1961.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court order, and remanded for inquiry into value under O.45 r.1 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: We would therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order passed by the High Court and remand the case to the High Court to decide the application for leave in accordance with the observations made in this judgment. The High Court may either hold the inquiry itself or remit the case to the Trial Court to hold such inquiry and report to it. Accordingly, the appeal is allowed and the High Courts order is set aside.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment
Art. 133 1  a  and  b  of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Appellant entitled to contend at leave application that property value is not less than Rs. 20,000/- since original application under s.84(2) Madras Act 1927 had fixed court fee and was converted to suit

anchor.surface_text: The suit in the first instance was filed by him in the form of an application, being O.P. No. 37 of 1950 under s. 84 2  of Madras Act 11 of 1927. Under that Act only a fixed court fee was payable... He was therefore entitled to contend at the time of the leave application that the property in dispute was of the value of not less than Rs. 20,000/-

arguments.claim: Property originally site of Kuppaiyan, purchased by appellant's ancestor Thoguluva Thirumalayyan in 1882 auction execution for Rs.1,060/-, improved with shops and constructions funded by descendants, belongs to Thoguluva family as alienable private property

anchor.surface_text: It does not appear to be in dispute that the site of the Mandapam and the structure standing thereon was originally the property of one Kuppaiyan and his undivided sons. The appellants case was that in execution of the decree in Suit No. 650 of 1882... and therefore the property belonged to and was an alienable private property of the family.

arguments.claim: Property is public temple for public religious worship and plaintiff's allegation that it is private property capable of alienation is false and misleading

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the case of the respondents in their written statement was that the property was a public temple for public religious worship and that the allegation of the plaintiff that it was a private property capable of alienation was false and misleading.

arguments.claim: Shops let out to tenants for years, property taxes levied by municipality on rateable value; tax for 1950 half-year Rs.94-0-6 and 1961 Rs.130.36nP equivalent to one month's rent, annual rental Rs.1,126-6-0 (1950) and Rs.1,672.32nP (1961), capitalized at 20 times exceeds Rs.20,000/-

anchor.surface_text: There was evidence that the shops subsequently constructed as aforesaid were let out to tenants for a number of years and property taxes were levied thereon by the Madhurai Municipality... According to him the half yearly tax would be equivalent to one months rent and on that basis the annual rental value would come to Rs. 1,126-6-0 in 1950 and to Rs. 1,672.32nP in 1961. If that be so, capitalising that value at twenty times the annual rental value, the value of the property would come to more than Rs. 20,000/-

arguments.court_reasoning: If that be so, capitalising... value ... more than Rs. 20,000/-

arguments.claim: High Court wrong in assuming property incapable of valuation whether private or public temple; subject-matter of dispute ascertained with reference to plaintiff's plaint claim of private family property capable of alienation, so High Court ought to value accordingly

anchor.surface_text: The refusal of the High Court to grant leave was based on the observation that whether the property is a private or a public temple, it was incapable of valuation. But as observed earlier the appellants case was that the subject- matter of dispute in the suit was the private property... the High Court ought to have valued the property accordingly though according to the respondents the property was inalienable and was a public temple.

holdings.text: The High Court was not right in assuming that whether the property was a private or a public temple, it was incapable of valuation.

anchor.surface_text: That being the dispute between the parties, the High Court was number right in assuming that whether the property was a private or a public temple, it was incapable of valuation. The subject-matter of the dispute has to be ascertained with reference to the claim made by the plaintiff in his plaint and since according to the plaint, the property is the private property of the said family capable of alienation, the High Court ought to have valued the property accordingly though according to the respondents the property was inalienable and was a public temple.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dispute centers on whether property is private alienable family property (per plaint) or public inalienable temple; cannot pre-judge nature to deny valuation but must value per plaintiff's claim under Art. 133.

holdings.text: Clause (b) of Art. 133(1) could apply as the judgment involves a claim respecting property whose value requires inquiry based on plaint.

anchor.surface_text: The refusal of the High Court to grant leave was based on the observation that whether the property is a private or a public temple, it was incapable of valuation. But as observed earlier the appellants case was that the subject- matter of dispute in the suit was the private property of the said family and that it was alienable property and therefore capable of a valid transfer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court's dismissal of cl. (b) based on no property claim of Rs. 20,000/- overlooks need to inquire value per plaintiff's private property claim in plaint.

holdings.text: The subject-matter of the dispute has to be ascertained with reference to the claim made by the plaintiff in his plaint and since according to the plaint, the property is the private property of the said family capable of alienation, the High Court ought to have valued the property accordingly.

anchor.surface_text: The subject-matter of the dispute has to be ascertained with reference to the claim made by the plaintiff in his plaint and since according to the plaint, the property is the private property of the said family capable of alienation, the High Court ought to have valued the property accordingly though according to the respondents the property was inalienable and was a public temple. The High Court was thus wrong in proceeding on the aforesaid assumption.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Valuation for Art. 133 certificate determined by reference to plaint's claim of private alienable property, not defendant's denial or pre-judged nature.

holdings.text: The appellant was entitled to contend at the time of the leave application that the property in dispute was of the value of not less than Rs. 20,000/- because the suit originated as an application under s. 84(2) of Madras Act 11 of 1927 with fixed court fee.

anchor.surface_text: Under that Act only a fixed companyrt fee was payable. That being so, the appellant did number have to pay companyrt fees as it would in the case of an ordinary suit on a valuation made by him therefor. The application was subsequently companyverted into a suit by an order of the High Court. He was therefore entitled to companytend at the time of the leave application that the property in dispute was of the value of number less than Rs. 20,000/-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fixed court fee in original O.P. under special Act did not require ad valorem fee based on valuation, so plaintiff entitled to assert value for Art. 133 leave.

holdings.text: The High Court was thus wrong in proceeding on the aforesaid assumption.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was thus wrong in proceeding on the aforesaid assumption. We would therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order passed by the High Court and remand the case to the High Court to decide the application for leave in accordance with the observations made in this judgment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Error in assuming incapacity of valuation necessitates remand for proper consideration under Art. 133.

holdings.text: Remand the case to the High Court to decide the application for leave in accordance with the observations made in this judgment. The High Court may either hold the inquiry itself or remit the case to the Trial Court to hold such inquiry and report to it under O. 45, r. 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: We would therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order passed by the High Court and remand the case to the High Court to decide the application for leave in accordance with the observations made in this judgment. The High Court may either hold the inquiry itself or remit the case to the Trial Court to hold such inquiry and report to it. Accordingly, the appeal is allowed and the High Courts order is set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: To enable proper inquiry into subject-matter value for Art. 133 certificate as per directions on plaint-based valuation.

anchor.surface_text: We would therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order passed by the High Court and remand the case to the High Court to decide the application for leave in accordance with the observations made in this judgment. The High Court may either hold the inquiry itself or remit the case to the Trial Court to hold such inquiry and report to it. Acc

anchor.surface_text: That being the dispute between the parties, the High Court was number right in assuming that whether the property was a private or a public temple, it was incapable of valuation. The subject-matter of the dispute has to be ascertained with reference to the claim made by the plaintiff in his plaint and since according to the plaint, the property is the private property of the said family capable of alienation, the High Court ought to have valued the property accordingly though according to the respondents the property was inalienable and was a public temple.

The refusal of the High Court to grant leave was based on the observation that whether the property is a private or a public temple, it was incapable of valuation. But as observed earlier the appellants case was that the subject- matter of dispute in the suit was the private property of the said family and that it was alienable property and therefore capable of a valid transfer.

We would therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order passed by the High Court and remand the case to the High Court to decide the application for leave in accordance with the observations made in this judgment. The High Court may either hold the inquiry itself or remit the case to the Trial Court to hold such inquiry and report to it. Acc
